intro.description: Welcome to the MetaWare IDE New Project Tutorial. This tutorial will help you understand how to create a new project and have the MetaWare IDE manage your entire build environment.

item.title: Create a Project
item.description:
Create a C/C++ project by selecting the menu item:
File > New > C Project. You now see the New Project wizard.

item.title: Name Your Project
item.description:
Enter a name (such as HelloWorld) for the project. You can also enter a new path for your project by deselecting the Use Default Location checkbox and entering the new path in the Directory: text box.
Don't click Next until you've chosen a project type and toolchain.

item.title: Select a Project Type
item.description:
Choose a project type:
Executable
Shared library
Static library
Makefile - Empty project for importing existing makefile-based projects.
For this tutorial, choose Executable. Don't click Next until you choose a toolchain.

item.title: Select a Toolchain
item.description:
Click a toolchain in the Toolchain box. The default is ARC4 for ARCtangent-A4. For other ARC targets, choose ARCompact. Later you can further specify your exact ARCompact-based processor.
After you click Next, the Select Configurations dialog appears.

item.title: Select Your Configurations
item.description:
Configurations describe the build settings for your executable, since you probably want different settings for debugging and release. You can even create your own configuration. For this tutorial, accept the defaults and click Advanced settings....
The Properties dialog for your project appears.

item.title: View the Properties Dialog
item.description: In the Properties dialog you can change default settings for your project. Expand C/C++ Build and select Settings.

item.title: Specify the Tool Settings
item.description: In the Properties dialog you can change default settings for your project. Expand C/C++ Build and select Settings. For ARCompact, select Processor/Extensions and select your exact ARC Core Version from the drop-down list.

item.title: Exit the Properties Dialog
item.description:
In an actual project, you can make other selections as well. For now, click OK.
Your new project appears in the Project Explorer.

item.title: Create a File
item.description: Create a new C file by right-clicking your project and selecting New > File.

item.title: Use the New File Wizard
item.description:
The New File wizard appears.
Enter the name of your file (such as hello.c) in the File name: text area, and click Finish.

item.title: View the New Project File
item.description: The new file is visible under your project in the Project Explorer, and is open in the Editor view.

item.title: Enter Code
item.description:
Enter the code in the hello.c file that you created. You can double click the hello.c tab in the Editor view to expand the view.
Notice the asterisk left of the file name on the tab. The asterisk indicates that the file has changed but has not been saved.

item.title: Step Through the Code
item.description:
Notice that the Outline view is now populated with objects created from your code.
If you select an item from the Outline view, the corresponding code is highlighted in the editor.

item.title: Save the File
item.description:
Now save the hello.c file by clicking File > Save, and build your project by typing Ctrl+b.
You can read through the build messages in the Console view. When the project builds successfully, the Console view shows the following message:
Finished building target: hello.elf

item.title: View the Executable
item.description: Expand the Binaries item under your project in the Project Explorer. You now see the executable ELF file listed.

item.title: Run the Application
item.description:
You can run your application within the C/C++ Perspective. To do so click Run > Run...
Your file runs to completion. The Console view displays the output.
